columns.text: In this problem, we will look at how the different variables affect the degree of operating leverage.

Moreover, we can also recall that the formula for OCF, when taxes are considered, is given as:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{OCF}&=[(\text{P}-\text{v})\times \text{Q}-\text{FC}]\times(1-\text{T})+(\text{T}\times \text{D})
\end{aligned}$$

Factoring out $\text{OCF}_{\text{old}}$, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{DOL}&=\dfrac{\text{OCF}_{\text{old}}}{\text{OCF}_{\text{old}}}+\dfrac{-(\text{T} \times \text{D})+\text{FC}\times(1-\text{T})}{\text{OCF}_{\text{old}}}\\[15 pt]
&=1+\dfrac{-(\text{T} \times \text{D})+\text{FC}\times(1-\text{T})}{\text{OCF}_{\text{old}}}\\
\end{aligned}$$

If we set $\text{T}=0$, the formula will be the same as the first formula in Step 1 since it will cancel out the value of depreciation as it assumes that at the end of the lifespan, the value depreciates to zero.
